Description: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT A BROAD SAMPLING FOR DUNG SAMPLES FOR BOTH SPECIES, AND TO DEVELOP NOVEL METHODS TO IMPROVE DNA PRESERVATION FROM DUNG, BETTER IDENTIFY DISTINCT MATERNAL LINEAGES, AND IDENTIFY SIRE LINEAGES  GRANTEE WILL INITIATE A PROJECT TO STORE AND GROW CELLS, TO ALLOW FOR EXTRACTION OF HIGH QUALITY DNA AND TO ENABLE IN VITRO AND GENOMIC STUDIES ON A LONGER TERM BASIS  THE PROJECT EXPECTS FOR EACH SPECIES   1  WIDESPREAD SAMPLING OF DUNG FROM WILD RHINOS   2  DEVELOPMENT OF IMPROVED DUNG COLLECTION METHODS   3  HIGH THROUGHPUT SEQUENCING  HTS  TO BE USED ON DNA FROM DUNG SAMPLES   4  MATERNAL LINEAGES IDENTIFIED MORE ACCURATELY AND PRECISELY BY EXTRACTING FULL MITOGENOMES FROM HTS  THE HTS READS WILL ALSO IDENTIFY DIET AND PATHOGENS   AND  5  NOVEL Y CHROMOSOME HAPLOTYPE MARKERS DEVELOPED AND USED TO IDENTIFY PATERNAL LINEAGES  THE NEXT GENERATION SEQUENCES FROM DUNG SAMPLES WILL PERMIT RHINOCEROS DIET AND INTESTINAL PARASITES TO BE EXAMINED  THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL CONTRIBUTE TO A GROWING BODY OF GENOMIC REFERENCES OF SOUTHEAST ASIAN FLORA, WHICH WILL BE SHARED WITH ECOLOGICAL RESEARCHERS AND PROVIDE VITAL INFORMATION TO HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS LOCALLY

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE TO SUPPORT THE SALARY OF 15 ADDITIONAL GUARDS (WHO ARE IN ADDITION TO THE EXISTING STAFF OF THE FOREST DEPARTMENT) FOR 24 MONTHS, TO PATROL AND MONITOR THE RHINO HABITATS IN MANAS NATIONAL PARK (MNP). PREFERENCE WILL BE GIVEN TO PERSONS FROM THE ADJACENT VILLAGES TO IMPROVE THE SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS OF THE VILLAGERS, AND TO DEVELOP A GOOD RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE MNP MANAGEMENT AND THE VILLAGERS ADJACENT TO MNP. SPECIAL TRAINING OF THE NEWLY RECRUITED GUARDS ON WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND TO COMBAT POACHING WILL BE PROVIDED BY THE FOREST DEPARTMENT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO STABILIZE AND INCREASE THE TIGER POPULATION BY 50%, FROM EIGHT TIGERS (2018 SURVEY) TO 12 TIGERS BY 2025, WITH AT LEAST FOUR FEMALE AND TWO MALE TIGERS PERSISTING FOR THREE YEARS OR LONGER. THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE AS FOLLOWS: (1) ANNUALLY UPDATE STATUS OF TIGER AND PREY POPULATIONS IN THE CORE AREA; (2) ADDRESS CRITICAL THREATS TO TIGERS IN THE CORE AREA; AND (3) DESIGN HIGHLY TARGETED PRACTICAL INTERVENTION MEASURES, SUCH AS COORDINATE A PENINSULA-WIDE THREAT ASSESSMENT TO THE MALAYAN TIGER AND DEVELOP TARGETED INTERVENTION STRATEGIES FOR SPECIFIC PROBLEMS, TO ADDRESS THE MOST PRESSING THREATS TO TIGERS IN PENINSULAR MALAYSIA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) STRENGTHEN THE SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL (SMART) PATROL SYSTEM IN THAP LAN THROUGH PARK RANGER TRAINING, MORALE BOOSTING SUPPORT, AND MONITORING PERFORMANCE; (2) ENHANCE GRASS-BASED OPEN FOREST AREAS TO BOOST UNGULATE POPULATIONS IN THAP LAN BY USING HABITAT MANAGEMENT TOOLS; (3) ESTIMATE THE DENSITY OF UNGULATES IN THE CORE AREA OF THAP LAN WITH DISTANCE PROGRAM SAMPLING TECHNIQUES; AND (4) RENOVATE AN OLD RANGER STATION TO A FIELD WILDLIFE RESEARCH STATION FOR RESEARCHERS AND RANGER FIELD TEAMS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SECURE STRONG CONVICTION OUTCOMES FOR TIGERS AND OTHER WILDLIFE CRIMES, WHICH WILL HAVE A SECONDARY EFFECT OF PREVENTING THE CONTINUED LOSS OF THE MALAYAN TIGER POPULATION. THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED BY WORKING CLOSELY WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND NATIONAL PARKS PENINSULAR MALAYSIA (DWNP) LEGAL AND ENFORCEMENT TEAMS (THE KEY BENEFICIARIES OF CAPACITY BUILDING), PUBLIC PROSECUTORS AND THE ROYAL MALAYSIAN POLICE TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING THREE OBJECTIVES: (1) BY MONTH 36, AT LEAST 50% OF THE ENFORCEMENT TEAM TARGETED BY THE PROJECT SHOW IMPROVEMENT IN THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND PROFICIENCY TO INVESTIGATE CRIMES INVOLVING TIGERS AND THEIR PREY; (2) BY MONTH 36, ACHIEVE AT LEAST 50% OF THE PROSECUTED TIGER AND OTHER TOTALLY PROTECTED WILDLIFE CASES TRIED BY DWNP LEAD TO A CONVICTION; AND (3) BY MONTH 36, AT LEAST 50% OF CONVICTED CASES SEE PENALTIES IN ACCORDANCE TO THE WILDLIFE CRIME SENTENCING GUIDELINE PRODUCED UNDER THE PROJECT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONSERVE AND SUSTAIN THE POPULATION OF TIGERS IN AND AROUND THE ENDAU-ROMPIN LANDSCAPE. PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: (1) STRENGTHEN WILDLIFE PROTECTION EFFORTS THROUGH IMPROVED COORDINATION AMONG AGENCIES THROUGH A SMART (SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL) PATROL DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AMONG THE JOHOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION PROJECT, CAPACITY BUILDING AND ON THE JOB TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO IMPLEMENT AN ANTI-POACHING AND PATROLLING STRATEGY IN THE ENDAU-ROMPIN LANDSCAPE, AND MONITOR AND GENERATE INFORMATION ON THREATS TO ADDRESS INFORMATION GAPS; (2) MONITOR TIGER POPULATION TRENDS IN THE ENDAU-ROMPIN LANDSCAPE THROUGH A CAMERA TRAP SURVEY AND ESTIMATE TIGER POPULATION DENSITY; AND (3) DEVELOP MANAGEMENT PLAN GUIDELINES TO SECURE TIGER HABITATS AND MAINTAIN CONNECTIVITY AT PRIORITY CORRIDORS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SOLIDIFY THE RECOVERY OF TIGERS IN THAILAND'S DONG PHAYAYEN-KHAO YAI (DPKY) FOREST COMPLEX AND SECURE THE DISPERSAL TO CONNECTED ENVIRONS INCLUDING BANTAEY CHHMAR PROTECTED LANDSCAPE (BCPL) IN CAMBODIA. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE AS FOLLOWS: (1) IMPROVE STRATEGIC ENFORCEMENT IN DPKY AND BCPL; (2) EXPAND MONITORING TO INCREASE UNDERSTANDING OF TIGER POPULATION DYNAMICS AND DISPERSAL TO CONNECTED HABITAT; AND (3) EXPAND WIDER SUPPORT FOR THE CONSERVATION OF TIGERS, PREY AND BIODIVERSITY IN DPKY, BCPL AND THE DANGRAK ECOLOGICAL CORRIDOR.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) UNDERSTAND TIGER DISPERSAL POTENTIAL IN THE WESTERN FOREST COMPLEX (WEFCOM) USING A LANDSCAPE MODEL DEVELOPED TO INTEGRATE DISPERSAL MOVEMENTS, PREDICT TIGER AND PREY OCCUPANCY AND IDENTIFY AREAS FOR MANAGEMENT; (2) CREATE A TIGER DATA DATABASE AT KHAO NANG RAM RESEARCH STATION FOR THE PERIOD 2007 TO PRESENT TO ESTABLISH A COMMON IDENTIFICATION SYSTEM LINKING COLLARED TIGER IDS FROM MULTIPLE PROJECTS AND INCORPORATE INTO AN EXISTING WEFCOM SPATIAL DATABASE COMPOSED OF THE PROBABILITY OF HABITAT OCCUPANCY BY TIGERS AND THEIR PRIMARY PREY; (3) DEVELOP AND CONDUCT CONSERVATION EDUCATION WORKSHOPS AT NINE KEY KAREN VILLAGES IN THUNG YAI EAST AND WEST TO BUILD A PROGRAM TO INCREASE COMMUNITY CONSERVATION AND REDUCE SUBSISTENCE HUNTING; AND (4) DEVELOP AND CONDUCT TWO WORKSHOPS WITH PROTECTED AREA CHIEFS, REGIONAL DNP RESEARCH STAFF, LOCAL AND INTERNATIONAL NGOS TO CREATE A STRATEGIC PLAN TO EXPAND THE DISTRIBUTION OF TIGER BREEDING HABITAT TO THE 63% OF WEFCOM WHERE TIGERS ARE NOT CURRENTLY BREEDING.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUSTAIN THE RECOVERY OF TIGERS, CO-PREDATORS AND THEIR PREY ACROSS TRANSBOUNDARY MANAS CONSERVATION AREA OF INDIA. THE OBJECTIVES AND ASSOCIATED ACTIVITIES ARE AS FOLLOWS: (1) IDENTIFYING THE RECOVERY POTENTIAL FOR TIGERS, CO-PREDATORS AND PREY RECOVERY IN MANAS TIGER RESERVE; ACTIVITIES: (1.1) SET BASELINES FOR POPULATION AND COMMUNITY STRUCTURE OF TIGERS, CO-PREDATORS AND PREY IN THE MANAS TIGER RESERVE IN INDIA; (1.2) BUILD FIELD AND ANALYTICAL CAPACITY AMONGST PARK MANAGEMENT AND GRASSROOTS NGO VOLUNTEERS TO CONDUCT AND ANALYZE BIOLOGICAL MONITORING INFORMATION FOR SUSTAINED RECOVERY; (2) DEVELOPING A COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN TO SECURE FUTURE TIGER, CO-PREDATOR AND PREY POPULATIONS; ACTIVITIES: (2.1) DEVELOP A TIGER, CO-PREDATORS AND PREY RECOVERY ROAD MAP IN COLLABORATION WITH THE MANAS TIGER RESERVE MANAGEMENT; (3) EXPERIMENTING WITH COMMUNITY-LED HABITAT RESTORATION PRACTICES TO SUSTAIN SPECIES RECOVERY IN MANAS TIGER RESERVE, INDIA; ACTIVITIES: (3.1) DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT EXPERIMENTAL HABITAT RESTORATION PLOTS ACROSS THE MANAS TIGER RESERVE; (3.2) MONITOR AND EVALUATE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES TO IDENTIFY THE BEST PRACTICES OF HABITAT RESTORATION IN MANAS TIGER RESERVE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) OPTIMIZE AND INSTITUTIONALIZE SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL (SMART) PATROLLING SYSTEMS AT FEDERAL-LEVEL PROTECTED AREAS WITH TIGERS, AND EXPAND THE USE OF SMART IN THE NORTHERN PORTION OF TIGER HABITAT IN THE RUSSIAN FAR EAST; 2) SUSTAIN AND, WHERE NECESSARY, IMPLEMENT MONITORING PROGRAMS AT KEY SITES TO DOCUMENT POPULATION TRENDS OF TIGERS AND THEIR PREY; AND (3) CONDUCT ECOLOGICAL STUDIES OF PREY SPECIES TO BETTER INFORM CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT DECISIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SAVE THE METAPOPULATIONS OF TIGER, ELEPHANT AND GIBBON IN THE NORTHEAST REGION OF INDIA. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE AS FOLLOWS: (1) UNDERSTAND ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF KEY THREATENED SPECIES IN THE LANDSCAPE; (2) EVALUATE THE HABITATS OF KEY THREATENED SPECIES AND CONNECTIVITY CORRIDORS WITHIN THE LANDSCAPE; (3) EVALUATE THE CONSERVATION THREATS TO THE KEY SPECIES, THEIR HABITATS AND CONNECTIVITY CORRIDORS IN THE LANDSCAPE AND ASSESS CURRENT CONSERVATION ACTIONS IN PLACE; AND (4) UNDERSTAND LANDSCAPE AND LOCAL LEVEL CONSERVATION SCENARIOS IN RELATION TO HUMAN DEPENDENCE ON NATURAL RESOURCES AND ITS IMPACT ON SPECIES AND HABITATS IN THE LANDSCAPE.
DETERRING WILDLIFE CRIME AND ILLEGAL WILDLIFE TRAFFICKING OF RHINOCEROS AND TIGER BODY PARTS IN THE TRANSBOUNDARY EASTERN HIMALAYAS

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO FOSTER GREATER CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP THROUGH CITIZEN ACTIONS WITH THE FOLLOWING THREE-PRONGED APPROACH: EXPANDING WILDLIFE AND HABITAT PROTECTION THROUGH COMMUNITY RANGER (CR) AND CITIZEN ACTION FOR TIGERS (CAT) WALK PATROLS, WHICH ARE FOOT PATROLS IN TIGER HABITAT, WITH ADDED ADAPTIVE STRATEGIES; INCREASING PUBLIC INVOLVEMENT IN TIGER CONSERVATION THROUGH CAT WALKS; AND FOSTERING AN ORGANIC AND ACTIVE CONSERVATION FOCUSED COMMUNITY WITHIN CAT WALK ALUMNI. THE PROJECT HAS THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES AND ACTIVITIES: (1) ENSURE TIGER, WILDLIFE AND HABITAT ARE PROTECTED AGAINST ANY ILLEGAL ACTIVITIES SURROUNDING THE SUNGAI YU CORRIDOR WITH (A) TARGETED AND COORDINATED PATROLS IN KEY AREAS WITH SUPPORTING PATROLS IN LESS ACCESSIBLE ZONES; (B) CONDUCT JOINT PATROLS, AND OUTREACH WITH THE DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE AND NATIONAL PARKS (DWNP), ROYAL MALAYSIAN POLICE (RMP), AND STATE FOREST DEPARTMENT; (C) OPERATION OF WILDLIFE CRIME HOTLINE AND COORDINATION WITH THE DWNP AND RMP; AND (2) INCREASED CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP AND EXPANSION OF CAT WALKS BY (A) EXPANDING NUMBER OF CAT WALKS TAPPING INTO LOCAL CONSERVATION NETWORKS, SOCIAL MEDIA, WILDLIFE ENTHUSIAST GROUPS, AND ESPECIALLY THE ECO-TOURISM MARKET NETWORK BOTH NATIONALLY, REGIONALLY, AND ON A GLOBAL SCALE; (B) IDENTIFYING, TRAINING, AND MENTORING NEW VOLUNTEER LEADERS FOR CAT WALKS; (C) IDENTIFYING NEW AREAS TO EXPAND CAT WALKS INTO; AND (D) FOSTERING CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP BEYOND CAT WALKS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE HUMAN - LARGE CARNIVORE CONFLICT AND FACILITATE CO-EXISTENCE OF PEOPLE AND WILDLIFE IN THE BUFFER FOREST OF TADOBA ANDHARI TIGER RESERVE. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE, (1) EDUCATION FOR SENSITIZED AND AWARE COMMUNITIES OF 92 VILLAGES; (2) LOCAL LEADERSHIP FOR MITIGATION, WHICH INCLUDES CREATING PRIMARY RESPONSE TEAMS IN 92 VILLAGES, WHO WILL BE THE FIRST RESPONDERS IN HUMAN-TIGER CONFLICT MITIGATION; (3) PROTECTION OF WILDLIFE AND HABITAT; (4) COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION IN MITIGATION IN HIGH CONFLICT VILLAGES; AND (5) UNDERSTANDING TOLERANCE FOR BETTER MITIGATION PLANNING.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO GUARANTEE THE SURVIVAL OF THE SUMATRAN TIGER IN THE BUKIT TIGA PULUH NATIONAL PARK BY STRENGTHENING THE CAPACITY OF THE BUKIT TIGA PULUH NATIONAL PARK (TNBT) AND EMPOWERING LOCAL SCOUTS TO PROTECT AND MONITOR THE SUMATRAN TIGER POPULATION, ITS HABITAT AND ITS PREYS.THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT ARE:1) IMPLEMENTING AN EFFECTIVE AND EFFICIENT PATROL SYSTEM WITH FOCUS ON JOINT PATROLS BETWEEN PARK RANGERS AND COMMUNITY-BASED SCOUTS IN BUKIT TIGA PULUH NATIONAL PARK2) STRENGTHENING THE CAPACITY OF PATROL TEAMS THROUGH ADVANCED TRAINING AND SMART, AND BUILD SUSTAINABILITY FOR BUKIT TIGA PULUH NATIONAL PARK3) MONITORING OF TIGERS, TIGER PREY SPECIES AND THEIR HABITAT WITH CAMERA TRAPS AND REMOTE SENSING OF FOREST COVERAGE IN BUKIT TIGA PULUH NATIONAL PARK
PROTECTING TIGERS IN THE BANGLADESH SUNDARBANS THROUGH STRENGTHENED SMART PATROLS AND BETTER DETECTION AND UNDERSTANDING OF WILDLIFE CRIME

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS ENHANCING THE CONSERVATION OF TIGERS, ASIAN RHINOS, AND OTHER ENDANGERED WILDLIFE IN ASIA THROUGH IMPROVED VETERINARY CAPACITY IN THE RANGE COUNTRIES BY IMPARTING KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO LOCAL VETERINARIANS IN DISEASE INVESTIGATION, SURVEILLANCE, AND OTHER CONSERVATION THREATS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE AS FOLLOWS: (1) IDENTIFY LOCAL AND OUT OF REGION SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS IN WILDLIFE VETERINARY MEDICINE, VETERINARY PATHOLOGY, EPIDEMIOLOGY, ECOLOGY, AND WILDLIFE POPULATION MANAGEMENT; (2) HOST ONLINE VIDEO CONFERENCES IN 2022 FOR WILDLIFE VETERINARIANS WITH SUBJECT MATTER EXPERTS TO ESTABLISH NETWORKING, ASSESS THE NEEDS OF WILDLIFE VETERINARIANS AND DISSEMINATE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS FOR IMPROVED DISEASE INVESTIGATION AND SURVEILLANCE; (3) HOST HANDS-ON LABORATORY TRAINING SESSIONS AT THE CENTRE FOR WILDLIFE RESEARCH AND FORENSICS (INDIA), AND AT THE NTNC BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION CENTRE LABORATORY (NEPAL) IN 2023; AND (4) SUPPORT 10 VETERINARIANS TO TRAVEL TO AND PARTICIPATE IN THE ONE WEEK (FIVE DAYS) HANDS-ON FIELD TRAINING COURSES IN EACH OF THE TWO LABORATORIES IN ORDER TO BUILD THEIR INDIVIDUAL CAPACITY AND ENHANCE THEIR WILDLIFE VETERINARY EXPERTISE TO MORE EFFECTIVELY INVESTIGATE AND MONITOR DISEASE AND ASSIST CONSERVATION EFFORTS. DUE TO THE CURRENT SITUATION IN ASIA WITH INCREASED COVID-19 CASES AND TRAVEL RESTRICTIONS, THIS WILL BE A TWO-YEAR PROJECT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) FURTHER REDUCE THREATS TO TIGER, TIGER PREY SPECIES AND HABITAT THROUGH SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL (SMART) FOREST PATROLS, INVESTIGATIONS, HUMAN-TIGER CONFLICT MITIGATION AND WILDLIFE AND FOREST LAW ENFORCEMENT; (2) MITIGATE HUMAN-TIGER CONFLICTS TO PROTECT BOTH TIGER AND FOREST-EDGE COMMUNITIES; AND (3) INCREASE KNOWLEDGE AND INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY TO CONSERVE TIGER AND OTHER ENDANGERED SPECIES AMONG LOCAL AND NATIONAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, CIVIL SOCIETY, LOCAL DECISION MAKERS, RELIGIOUS LEADERS, AND TRADITIONAL COMMUNITIES.

CONSERVATION OF TIGER, RHINO, ELEPHANTS AND HOOLOCK GIBBONS IN KAZIRANGA-KARBI ANGLONG LANDSCAPE USING PNRM APPROACH BY FOREST DEPENDENT INDIGENOUS KARBI TRIBE IN KOHORA AND DIFFOLU RIVER BASINS, INDIA

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) IDENTIFY MOVEMENT CORRIDORS FOR TIGER AND RHINO POPULATIONS IN INDO-NEPAL TERAI ARC LANDSCAPE; (2) CREATE TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE DATA LAYERS (CURRENT AND FUTURE ROAD NETWORK); (3) IDENTIFY CONFLICT SECTIONS OF TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS THAT LIMIT TIGER AND RHINO MOVEMENTS FOR MITIGATION PRIORITIZATION; AND (4) STRENGTHEN TRANSBOUNDARY CONNECTIVITY COORDINATION, SCIENCE IMPLEMENTATION AND CAPACITY BUILDING.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) INTEGRATE AN ID-BASED RHINO MONITORING SYSTEM WITH THE SMART (SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL) PATROLLING SYSTEM, DNA SAMPLING, AND BUILD INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY FOR IMPROVED MONITORING; (2) DEVELOP A PLAN FOR INTERNAL TRANSLOCATION OF RHINOS FROM HIGHLY CONCENTRATED AREAS TO SPARSELY POPULATED AREAS OF THE PARK; AND (3) ADDRESS THE CONCERN ABOUT AN ASSESSMENT OF WATER QUALITY IN WETLANDS USED BY RHINOS AND PROVIDE MANAGEMENT GUIDELINES OF THESE WETLANDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) PATROL THE FULL EXTENT AND BOUNDARIES OF WAY KAMBAS NATIONAL PARK (WKNP) AND MONITOR RHINOS AND OTHER THREATENED SPECIES; (2) CURTAIL ILLEGAL HUNTING AND TRAPPING OF WILDLIFE IN WKNP; (3) IMPROVE PATROLLING AND LAW ENFORCEMENT EFFECTIVENESS IN WKNP; (4) MAINTAIN PREVIOUSLY PLANTED 60 HECTARES AND REPLANT 90 HECTARES OF DEGRADED LAND WITH RHINO FOOD PLANTS; AND (5) PARTNER WITH PARK STAFF AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO PREVENT FURTHER ENCROACHMENT AND HABITAT DEGRADATION IN WKNP.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) PATROL THE FULL EXTENT AND BOUNDARIES OF UJUNG KULON NATIONAL PARK (UKNP) AND MONITOR RHINOS AND OTHER THREATENED SPECIES; (2) CURTAIL ILLEGAL HUNTING AND TRAPPING OF WILDLIFE; AND (3) ESTABLISH REAL-TIME SECURITY SYSTEM TO IMPROVE DETECTION OF AND REACTION TO ILLEGAL INCURSIONS; THE REAL-TIME SECURITY SYSTEM INCLUDES INSTALLATION OF REAL-TIME SECURITY SYSTEM CAMERAS, BUILDING AN OPERATIONS ROOM (WITH EQUIPMENT) AT PARK HEADQUARTERS, AND TRAINING STAFF ON OPERATION OF REAL-TIME SECURITY AND MONITORING SYSTEM.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SECURE THE BREEDING HABITAT AND POPULATION DISPERSAL OF TIGERS IN BIOLOGICAL CORRIDOR 4. THE PROJECT WILL HELP PREPARE A MANAGEMENT PLAN TO FOCUS ON PROTECTING TIGER HABITAT, STRENGTHEN SMART (SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL) PATROLLING, AND ENHANCE COMMUNITY AWARENESS ABOUT TIGER CONSERVATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESTORE TIGER HABITAT IN THE NEWLY DECLARED SRIVILLIPUTHUR-MEGAMALAI TIGER RESERVE (SMTR) IN TAMIL NADU. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: FORM JOINT FOREST MANAGEMENT COMMITTEES IN VILLAGES ADJACENT TO SMTR AND INVOLVE WOMEN ON THESE COMMITTEES, DEVELOP THE CAPACITIES OF FRONTLINE FOREST STAFF ON FOREST MANAGEMENT, PROVIDE ALTERNATE LIVELIHOOD TRAINING AND SUPPORT TO COMMITTEES, DEVELOP EDUCATION MODULES FOR LOCAL EDUCATORS FOR TIGER AND HABITAT CONSERVATION, SET UP A FOUNDATION FOR RESEARCH AT SMTR, AND EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF THE PROJECT.
STRENGTHENING HUMAN TIGER CO-EXISTENCE IN WESTERN TERAI LANDSCAPE IN NEPAL
GRASSLAND MANAGEMENT FOR REPLENISHING HABITATS TO BOOST CONSERVATION OF RHINO AND TIGER IN MANAS NATIONAL PARK AND POBITORA WILDLIFE SANCTUARY IN ASSAM, INDIA
IMPLEMENTING SWEFCOMS TIGER CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN: CONSOLIDATING BASELINES AND ADDRESSING CRITICAL THREATS
PROTECTION OF CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SUMATRAN TIGER, RHINO AND ELEPHANT POPULATIONS IN WAY KAMBAS NATIONAL PARK, SUMATRA
WILDLIFE CRIME DATABASE: A VITAL TOOL TO STRENGTHEN EFFORTS TO CURB TIGER POACHING AND TRADE, AND RELATED WILDLIFE CRIMES IN INDIA
PREVENTING HABITAT FRAGMENTATION AND SECURING FUTURE OF THE TIGERS IN NEPAL THROUGH BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF TIGER BEHAVIOR AND RESPONSE TO ROADS
REDUCING POACHING/IWT THREATS AND SUSTAINING THE GROWTH OF RHINOCEROS AND TIGER POPULATIONS IN CHITWAN-PARSA COMPLEX, NEPAL

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) REDUCE REMOVAL (CAPTURE) OF TIGERS AND LEOPARDS AS A RESULT OF CONFLICT SITUATIONS THROUGH AN EFFICIENT AND PROACTIVE RESPONSE MECHANISM AND TRAINED FRONTLINE STAFF; (2) INCREASE AND STRENGTHEN ENGAGEMENT AND PARTICIPATION OF LOCAL COMMUNITY REPRESENTATIVES, INCLUDING YOUTH, IN CONFLICT MANAGEMENT AND OTHER CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES; AND (3) SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCE TIGER AND LEOPARD ATTACKS ON PEOPLE IN FOUR PRIORITIZED HIGH CONFLICT VILLAGES IN THE LANDSCAPE.
RECOVERING TIGERS IN NEPAL: SECURING THE FUTURE OF EXPANDING POPULATIONS THROUGH ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES
STRENGTHENING THE RECOVERY OF TIGERS ACROSS THE TRANSBOUNDARY MANAS CONSERVATION AREA (TRAMCA) IN INDIA AND BHUTAN
SUMATRAN RHINO PROTECTION IN THE CORE AREA OF THE WESTERN LEUSER ECOSYSTEM
RECOVERING OF TIGERS THROUGH SMART PATROL, CONSERVATION EDUCATION, AND LONG-TERM POPULATION MONITORING IN THE WESTERN FOREST COMPLEX, THAILAND: SAVING THE TIGERS YEAR 13-15
PROTECTING AMUR TIGERS VIA COMMUNITY-LED ENGAGEMENT IN NORTHEAST CHINA
SECURING LIVELIHOODS AND REDUCING DEPENDENCE ON BIOMASS EXTRACTION FOR RECOVERY OF TIGER AND PREY POPULATIONS IN THE WESTERN GHATS, SOUTHERN INDIA
WILD SEVE: ADDRESSING HUMAN-TIGER CONFLICT IN INDIA'S WESTERN GHATS TIGER RESERVES
PROMOTING SUSTAINED GROWTH OF EASTERN BLACK RHINO (DICEROS BICORNIS MICHAELI) POPULATIONS AT OL PEJETA AND SERA CONSERVANCIES, KENYA
IMPROVED SECURITY AND MONITORING OF THE KEY 1 BLACK RHINO POPULATION IN THE TSAVO WEST NATIONAL PARK'S INTENSIVE PROTECTION ZONE, SOUTHERN KENYA - IN LINE WITH THE NATIONAL RHINO STRATEGY
SECURING THE GREATER NORTH LUANGWA LANDSCAPE FOR THE PROTECTION OF BLACK RHINOS (DICEROS BICORNIS MINOR) IN NORTH LUANGWA NATIONAL PARK, ZAMBIA
SUPPORT OF BLACK RHINOCEROS MONITORING AND PROTECTION IN THE GREATER SERENGETI ECOSYSTEM AND MKOMAZI NATIONAL PARK, NORTHERN TANZANIA.
CONSERVING THE NGORONGORO BLACK RHINO POPULATION IN NORTHERN TANZANIA
MAINTAINING BLACK RHINO SECURITY AND MONITORING IN THE CHYULU HILLS, KENYA - 2
FROM KEY 2 TO KEY 1: IMPROVING THE POPULATION STATUS OF BLACK RHINOS IN THE NORTH WEST PROVINCE, SOUTH AFRICA.
MATOPOS NATIONAL PARK: ANNUAL DARTING AND IMMOBILISATION OF BLACK AND WHITE RHINO FOR ROUTINE DEHORNING AND EAR-NOTCHING TO AID MONITORING AND PROTECTION STRATEGIES.
CONTINUED SUPPORT FOR RHINOCEROS MANAGEMENT OPERATIONS IN ZIMBABWE'S LOWVELD
THE AFRICAN RHINO SPECIALIST GROUP: GUIDING AND FACILITATING THE CONSERVATION OF VIABLE AFRICAN RHINO POPULATIONS ACROSS THEIR NATURAL RANGE
REINTRODUCTION OF BLACK RHINO INTO GONAREZHOU NATIONAL PARK, ZIMBABWE #2: LONG-TERM SECURITY THROUGH TARGETED TECHNOLOGY, PROTECTION AND MONITORING
PROTECTING THE RHINO POPULATIONS IN TWO OF KWAZULU-NATAL'S FLAGSHIP INTENSIVE PROTECTION ZONE PARKS, SOUTH AFRICA BY SUPPORTING RANGERS' WELFARE AND ABILITY TO DEPLOY INTO THE FIELD
PRIVATE-SECTOR SUPPORT FOR THE DELIVERY OF KENYA'S BLACK RHINO ACTION PLAN
PROTECTING AND MANAGING NAMIBIA'S KEY 1 AND KEY 2 BLACK RHINO POPULATIONS FOR MAXIMUM GROWTH
CONSERVATION OF THE TIGERS OF GUNUNG LEUSER NATIONAL PARK THROUGH IMPROVED LAW ENFORCEMENT AND REDUCED HUMAN-TIGER CONFLICT
CONSERVATION OF THE TIGERS OF BUKIT BARISAN SELATAN THROUGH IMPROVED LAW ENFORCEMENT AND REDUCED HUMAN-TIGER CONFLICT
ENHANCING TIGER CONSERVATION IN SHUKLAPHANTA NATIONAL PARK
CONSERVATION OF TIGERS THROUGH LAW ENFORCEMENT AND PREY POPULATION RECOVERY IN DONG PHAYAYEN -KHAO YAI FOREST COMPLEX, THAILAND
CONSERVATION OF TIGERS THROUGH LAW ENFORCEMENT, VOLUNTEER NETWORK, AND WILDLIFE STUDENT TRAINING IN THE WESTERN FOREST COMPLEX, THAILAND, YEAR 12
SMART ANTI-POACHING IN PROTECTED AND UNPROTECTED TIGER HABITAT IN RUSSIA

GUIDING AND FACILITATING THE CONSERVATION OF VIABLE AFRICAN RHINO POPULATIONS ACROSS THEIR NATURAL RANGE THROUGH THE
WORK OF THE IUCN SSC AFRICAN RHINO SPECIALIST GROUP (AFRSG)
